Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Ciliate Genomics Consortium Model for Sustainable Teaching-Research Integration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Engaging more undergraduates in research experiences is a priority for improving science education and course-based research experiences are a promising approach to reaching larger numbers of students. The Ciliate Genomics Consortium (CGC) is a student-centered, nation-wide collaborative learning community that uses scalable functional genomics research for integration into courses in a variety of biology sub-disciplines. The CGC employs an integrative teaching and research model that combines both inquiry-driven class laboratory activities and collaborative consortium pedagogies to advance faculty research. Previously, the CGC developed modular course-based research curricula that, when adopted by the research community using the ciliate Tetrahymena, effectively engaged greater numbers of students in authentic research while advancing faculty research. This work expands the consortium by creating new or improving tested curricula to promote their broad adoption, creating more opportunities for teaching/research integration. If successful, this project provide evidence that students in classroom settings can contribute substantially to faculty and community research priorities with a variety of model organisms.

To achieve project goals, the CGC will: 1) develop curricula adaptable to faculty research interests, integrate consortium activities with research community resources, and assess student learning gains; and 2) disseminate the CGC model through training workshops and assess the impact on faculty teaching and student learning. Curricula are disseminated through annual workshops and test whether research communities can foster learning communities that promote faculty adoption of classroom-based research as a high impact teaching practice. In this model, members of a research community form a professional learning community to enhance and apply best STEM teaching practices. To learn more about the effectiveness of this approach for both students and educators, the project will assess the pedagogy and report any conceptual gains this research-based curriculum offers over other instructional models, and present limitations and challenges observed. Several validated instruments will be used to measure confidence and learning gains with newly developed assessments to evaluate predicted cognitive gains. Cohorts of students at each institution are identified, not engaged in the CGC curriculum, to control for instructor and institutional factors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To increase the likelihood that students with interests in STEM fields obtain STEM degrees, colleges and universities must offer proven high impact experiences, such as course-integrated, authentic research. To facilitate educators? offering such formative experiences, the Ciliate Genomics Consortium (CGC), a student-centered collaborative learning community, developed an integrative teaching and research model that enables faculty to combine inquiry-based classroom teaching with their own research interests. This project set out to test the hypothesis that educators will effectively engage greater numbers of students in proven high impact experiences if given curricular tools and training to integrate authentic research into laboratory coursework. Faculty members are rewarded for their effort to improve teaching by achieving gains toward scholarship and research goals, which is a necessary measure for faculty academic success.

To test whether this integrative teaching-through-research approach would lead to change in teaching practice, the CGC offered annual 3 day workshops to train participating faculty members in the use of modular curriculum that enables flexible implementation to meet individuals? instructional goals. These hands-on workshops offered training in using specific laboratory exercises and advice on how to use them to advance one?s own research interests. Important outcomes achieved during the project included: 1) expansion of our professional learning community of scientist educators to provide a mutually supportive network to sustain adoption of high impact teaching; 2) development of diverse curricula that can match a wider range of courses and research interests by involving new members in this effort; 2) deeply integrating CGC curricular and web-publication resources with research community resources; and 4) disseminating our integrative teaching-research model to faculty members in other model system communities.

The successful expansion of the five founding CGC members to the more than twenty scientist educators is a Key Outcome underlying the Intellectual Merit of this project.  We observed new consortium members developing and sharing new curricular material that catalyzed further growth and diversification of the CGC learning community resources and adoption of these resources. The founding CGC members were united by their use of ciliated protozoa in their research projects.  Showing that the CGC integrative teaching-research was generalizable, the expanded members include of researchers who used non-ciliate study organisms including yeast, Hydra, Giardia, and fruit flies. Further showing that our strategy can be applied to other model-system-research communities, a daughter consortium of four fruit fly researchers was formed, inspired and supported by training we offered at workshops. Diversifying our curricular modules provided more entry points into gene function research, increased faculty/student participation, and diversified student contributions. Disseminating a database publication mechanism for student-generated data has improved understanding of methods to connect undergraduates with a research community. This has provided knowledge of many uncharacterized Tetrahymena genes, enhancing biological understanding in this useful model system - a proven catalyst for fundamental discoveries. Over the four years of the project, undergraduates at Washington University alone contributed functional annotation of 63 genes and the proteins that they encode, which represents a fraction of the intellectual contributions made by students engaged by CGC modular curricula.

A Key Outcome that demonstrated the Broader Impact of this integrative teaching-research project was our finding that the number of students engaged in our course-based authentic research grew approximately 8 fold from year 1 to year 4. The experience of doing science is expected to increase student motivation to pursue science degrees. The community context in which these experiences are offered can be particularly supportive of minority students in science, an outcome we continue to assess. The incorporation of undergraduates teaching assistants into workshops to train side-by-side with faculty members provided formative experiences for their futures as STEM leaders. The formation of this network of educators that support each other continues to enable them to adopt and sustain high-impact course-based student research that benefits their scholarship. The database that allows students to publish classroom-based research results provided real-time dissemination of the intellectual merit of the research finding and gave students credit for their work that they could cite on resumes or applications to support attainment of post-graduate educational training or employment. These general features of our project are structured for widespread adoption by faculty in any research community, thus increasing its potential for broad impact on student retention in STEM fields.
